description.narrative: Global Support Programme for Preparation of National Communications and Biennial Update Reports of non-Annex I Parties under the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC)
seat of a first-order administrative division

condition.narrative: Social and environmental sustainability will be enhanced through application of the UNDP Social and Environmental Standards (http://www.undp.org/ses) and related Accountability Mechanism (http://www.undp.org/secu-srm).
UNDP as the Implementing Partner will comply with the policies, procedures and practices of the United Nations Security Management System (UNSMS.)

description.narrative:
1. Government climate change policy making bodies from a sample of 10 countries are represented at the Director level or above, and equivalent for non-government, private sector and academic representatives by all sectors affected by and contributing to climate change. Additionally, the NC/BUR database supports the development of climate change relevant policies. In this means, increased awareness of importance of sound data collection, management and archiving among all different stakeholders in countries due to workshops is main indicator.
2. The indicator for technical backstopping to national teams for the preparation of NCs, BURs and INDCs is training of national experts compiling the NCs and BUR in the thematic & cross cutting areas defined by the UNFCCC reporting guidelines. Participants rate training, technical backstopping, supporting tools and guidance notes ‘high’ in helping them to prepare high quality BURs and National Communications, and in assisting them in the process of identifying, preparing, consulting and communication on nationally determined contributions to the Paris agreement.
3. In support of components 1 and 2, enhancing knowledge management, best practice, communication and outreach will be rated the networks highly by the experts and practitioners in providing them information and tools improve the quality of their National Communication and Biennial Update Reports.

comment.narrative:
1. Baseline: To achieve sustainable national institutional arrangements for climate change reporting, the level participation of government, non-government institutions, private sector and academic representatives in government climate change policy making bodies from a sample of 10 countries will be identified at the start of the project. Target: From the government climate change policy making bodies of these sample of 10 countries will be represented at the Director level or above, and equivalent for non-government, private sector, and academic representatives. Baseline: Additionally, from a sample of 10 countries, the percentage of sectors vulnerable to climate change that are represented on government climate change policy making bodies, at the start of the project. Target: 90% of sectors vulnerable to climate change from this sample of 10 countries will be represented at government climate change policy making bodies, at the end of project. Baseline: To achieve greater number of government ministries and provincial resources managers of the preparation and analyses of NCs and BURs, the baseline is the number of climate relevant policies from a sample of 10 countries developed between 2005-2010 supported by NC/BUR data. Target: achieve 80% of climate change relevant policies developed from the sample of 10 countries during the life of the project which are supported by data or information from the NC/BUR climate database.
2. Baseline: Available country expertise of the NCs, BURs and (I)NDCs will be measured during the first year of the project to establish the baseline in 10 sample countries. Target: from a representative sample of countries, national experts will have training and experience in all thematic & cross cutting areas defined by the UNFCCC reporting guidelines. This will enable to enhance technical capacities of the national teams to prepare better quality NCs, BURs and (I)NDCs. Target: From a 10 sample country survey of NC/ BUR/ nationally d

GSP target is to have at least 30 countries that have enhanced institutional arrangements for NC, BUR and GHG inventory preparation after receiving support from the GSP. -to have at least 50 countries that use BUR and NC data and analyses to inform planning processes at the national and subnational level. provide support to countries by engaging them at the level of preparation of TORs for different NC and BUR and their components, ensuring close alignment between the reporting guidelines and scope of work for the different NC and BUR studies, especially on mandatory reporting elements. GSP set a target of at least 70 countries to become members of a regional or language based MRV Networks.

Based on draft reports submitted to GSP for review, GSP noted a significant increase in countries that report on national institutional arrangements for sustainable NC and BUR preparation. Eight good examples of institutional arrangements from selected countries were prepared for inclusion in the GSP website. The main area of focus has been in enhancing GHG inventory data management and mitigation assessment in order to link with national NDC processes. This became the focus area of most countries in the Regional MRV networks (Annex 1), whereby concerted effort on GHG inventory data management was made or identified as the key capacity gap. GSP continued to provide draft report review support to the countries to identify remaining gaps in reporting, with a view to closing the identified gaps in the current or next reporting cycle, depending on national circumstances. Since 2016, GSP has reviewed 85 draft NCs, BUR and GHG inventory reports. More than 50% of supported countries have provided draft reports to GSP for review. Submission of draft reports to GSP for review is done on a voluntary basis, and some countries have opted to use independent Quality Assurance consultants. To date, out of the 126 countries enlisted in MRV Networks, at least 50 countries are active in in the regional MRV networks. The number is expected to grow with enhancement of MRV Network activities in the Asian region, where follow up MRV Network activities were impeded by the Covid-19 pandemic. Virtual engagement with the countries in the Networks is now being implemented.

-To encourage countries to access resources, to improve the qualities of their BURs, to submit them in due time and in more general terms in creating trust among key stakeholders on the BUR process and on the NC/BUR relevance not just for international reporting but also for domestic climate policies. Even if this outcome may not just depend on the GSP, the latter is a key international player in this area and can have a significant and substantial role in influencing BUR submission. -The program aims to have by the end of the project 135 Countries to have submitted their second NCs and 50 countries to have submitted their third NC. -At least 30 countries have enhanced institutional arrangements for NC, BUR and GHG inventory preparation after receiving support from the GSP -50 countries use BuR and NC data and analyses to inform planning processes at the national and subnational level

In this reporting period, the project has been fully successful, with an implementation rate of more than 90% of the 2020 budget and achieving all major goals and targets set up in the 2020 workplan, as validated by the steering committee in its December 15th meeting. During 2021, all main activities of the work plan were implemented. Among others, a training program on mitigation scenario and the use of the LEAP software in francophone cluster was held through 3 trainings in May 2021 (an average of 35 participants per session), in joint collaboration with GIZs PATPA. Similarly, the GSP led the organization and implementation of the annual MRV Group of Friend meeting, a coordination platform, in May with the participation of more than 30 stakeholders and UN agencies. Additional support and recommendations on MRV and institutional arrangements were also provided both bilaterally (e.g. supporting the establishment of MRV of Finance system in Georgia or the 2006 IPCC capacity building in Cote dIvoire ) as well as through the networks, by fostering knowledge exchanges on MRV and mitigation in Central Asia, on gender mainstreaming in Latin America, and enhancing institutional arrangements in the Agriculture and Forestry sector in anglophone Africa, in collaboration with FAO. The project is now expected to finalize shortly, in September 2021, with all its budget and outcomes achieved. Success by the project is confirmed not only by stakeholders and beneficiaries feedback but also by the fact that new resources by the donor will be provided to implement a second phase of the GSP for the period 2022-2027. While Covid 19 obliged the project to make a change of strategy, adaptive management allowed not only to reach previously established goals but to overachieve them, as in the reporting period 63 webinars were held by UNDP and UNEP, providing support to more than 120 countries in all regions, with the partial exception of the Arab peninsula countries, which will start receiving ad hoc, additional support during the project second phase. Delays: project was extended until 30 September 2021 by consensus decision of the Project Steering Committee held on December 15 2020. The project, which was meant to finalize on 31 March 2021, was extended for an additional 5 months to deal with two main aspects: a) lower project expenditure rate for 2020 due to unforeseen circumstances caused by COVID 19, as the highest budget item for 2020 was indeed workshops b) to ensure a smooth transition of support to developing countries toward the second phase of support, a project known as CBIT 2, to start in Q4 of 2021. Similarly, the Terminal Evaluation, to be developed under the leadership of UNEP in line with UNEPs Evaluation Office guidelines will be finalized before the end of the year 2021. Risks: as the GSP project comes to an end, it is the PM recommendation to maintain a continuous flow of support to developing countries on the topic through the quick start of the second phase of the project, called CBIT 2 in Q4 2021.
Overall, during the lifetime of the project, the GSP achieved all of its outcomes and outputs with a particularly positive feedback provided by developing countries representative who benefitted from this project. As highlighted in the network assessment survey, filled by 94 respondents from more than 50 countries, an overwhelming majority of the respondents, 72%, considered information they received through the network exchanges on the overall preparation of NCs/BURs extremely helpful, while an even higher share of respondents, 84%, reported that information shared on Monitoring Reporting and Verification components and Greenhouse gas inventories was extremely helpful. Further, thirty-seven regional workshops, thirty-six national workshops and more than sixty webinars have been organized, co-organized and/or co-funded by the GSP, counting with the participation of representatives from more than a 130 developing Countries. The GSP has also assisted 72 countries in reviewing 45 GHG inventories, 21 NCs, and 18 BURs. In addition, 26 countries have received request-based support, where GSP has reviewed technical terms of reference for experts. In addition to a high level of activity, the GSP has had a truly global reach: it has engaged 131 non-Annex I parties, and 85% of all non-Annex I parties, 90% of all least developed countries (LDCs), and 100% of all small island developing states (SIDS) have participated in GSP activities. It has also been able to respond to all country requests to date. In the course of the mid-term evaluation of the GSP, “Stakeholders interviewed uniformly expressed an appreciation of GSP support in terms of relevance, quality, and utility.”

Support voluntary national reviews of National Greenhouse Gas Inventory Management Systems Support the integration of gender responsive considerations into government climate change policy making bodies through inter alia the implementation of the document Gender responsive national communication toolkit Identify the domestic value of the information included in the BUR/NC as a way of fostering the use of NC/BUR data by all developing countries Support at least 3 meetings of the regional MRV networks

The project has assisted so far more than a 100 developing countries to enhance: a) institutional arrangements on monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) b) technical skills to comply with guidelines as agreed by the climate convention in the elaboration of Biennial Update Reports (BUR) and National Communications (NC) c) opportunities of knowledge exchanges among south/south and north/south collaboration lines d) accessing new BUR and NC resources from GEF before existing national projects finish.e) quality control before submission of BUR to the Convention. Such support has been praised in the mid term report and has increased the submission rate of NCs and BURs, as per below data. By 2019, 47 Countries have submitted the first Biennial Update Reports (BUR), 18 Countries have submitted the second BUR and only 5 Countries have submitted their third BUR. This sums to a total of 80 submissions, out of which 70 have happened since the Global Support Program (this project, in short GSP) has started providing its support. Further, BURs submitted are over time showing an increase in quality and frequency, as more countries use the 2006 IPCC guidelines, mention clearly their mitigation actions, enhance their institutional arrangements and identify specific gaps and needs . Suppord was provide to countries to enhance: a) institutional arrangements on monitoring, reporting and verification (MRV) b) technical skills to comply with guidelines as agreed by the climate convention in the elaboration of National Communications (NC) c) opportunities of knowledge exchanges among south/south and north/south collaboration lines d) accessing new BUR NC resources from GEF before existing national projects finish.e) quality control before the submission of NCs to the Convention. Solid institutional arrangements are one of the fundamental components for establishing solid national MRV systems capable of measuring emissions and progress. GSP has provided detailed support on such institutional issues mosty at the national level, as each country has different national circumstances that need in most cases ad hoc national solutions. So far, the GSP has supported voluntary national reviews of National Greenhouse Gas Inventory Management Systems thus dedicating significant time and effort in assistinting the enhancement of institutional arrangements in: 1) Namibia 2) Vietnam 3) Benin 4) Nigeria 5) Panama 6) Montenegro 7) Ecuador 8) Chile 9)Argentina and 10) Uruguay
In all those countries, among other things, the GSP encouraged and assisted in increasing participation in national climate arrangements as well as in enhancing its function and tasks. In particular, upon reccomendation provided by the GSP, in these 10 countries, national counterparts committed to raise the institutional arrangements on MRV so that high level policy makers will be directly part of such decision making bodies, ideally raising the strategical and political profile of NCs and BURs. The GSP considers women and LGBT groups among the most vulnerable to climate change and it is supporting the integration of gender responsive considerations into government climate change policy making bodies through inter alia the implementation of the document Gender responsive national communication toolkit elaborated by the GSP and available in three languages (English, Spanish and French). Gender support has been in particularly targeted to the Western Balkans region, where the Second Regional Workshop on Supporting the Integration of Gender Considerations into MRV/ Transparency Processes in the Western Balkan Countries and Lebanon was held in Belgrade, Serbia, in November 2018 with the participation of 31 participants (29 women and 2 men) from Albania, Bosnia Herzegovina, Lebanon, North Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia. GSP support was instrumental to implementing decisions by Bosnia Herzegovina, North Macedonia and Serbia to nominate UNFCCC gender focal points.
From a sample of 10 countries (Albania, Bosnia Herzegovina, Montenegro, North Macedonia, Serbia, Lebanon, Uruguay, Chile, Ecuador, Colombia) where the GSP has provided support, 8 countries (all minus Albania and Serbia) have now gender representatives directly engaged in climate change policy making bodies. From a sample of 10 countries supported by the GSP (North Macedonia, Montenegro, Chile, Uruguay, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Panama, Argentina, Lebanon), most of the new national climate policies, like NDCs, use information produced in GHG inventories submitted in the latest NC or BUR. 10 national voluntary reviews of the National Greenhouse Gas Inventory Management System and National Greenhouse Gas Inventories (for a total of 307 participants, of which 146 being women) - the third meeting of the Latin American network on GHG inventories (31 participants, of which 22 are women) - the second meeting of the Lusophone cluster (30 participants of which 12 women) - the second and third meeting of the Eurasian cluster (respectively 31 and 18 participants, of which 29 and 12 are women) - the kick off of the Caribbean MRV Hub (46 participants of which 25 were women) - the 9th meeting of the francophone cluster (63 participants, of which 22 were women) - a bilateral exchange between Armenia and Lebanon (15 participants, of which 9 were women) - Desk reviews of NCs, BURs and NIRs in 6 countries.
Since project inception, the GSP has supported 74 workshops/trainings, benefitting 2.719 experts, out of which 1467 are women.
